commentBody: HIED for hurried is one hell of a clue for a Tuesday
The King in question is a double decker and thus a checkers, not a chess piece.
Had a moment‚Äôs pause with HIED for [went in haste]. The immediate use of this verb that  came to mind is in the Scottish play as ‚ÄúHie thee hither‚Äù where it means to come.

The black squares in the graph reminded me of Space Invaders. 

Anyone else? No? Just me then.

Fun, challenging puzzle, but closer to a Wednesday in difficulty. 

L
A little chewy for a Tuesday. Got off to a great start  then found hot or not a huge not. Elo as a chess rating system is beyond my knowledge. Ended up faster than average but chewy.
Tuesday‚Äôs puzzle was a pain ‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶ Not!  Pretty fun for a Tuesday.
I am curious about the photo.  What‚Äôs it from?
I done did this puzz

It's old news that you can tell something of the constructor by the puzzle, choice of words, phrasing of clues...like those bro-puzzles with lots of PAC-10, umps, refs, Astros, Bruins, or the Gen-Z kind, more hipster. I get a feeling Gene likes it all, and would be a great person to hang out with, conversant on many topics, and wouldn't turn down some smoked salmon & caviar, followed by cigars, or see the irony in an O. Henry story. And when the photo shoot zooms in on Buddy Ebsen, you know this puzzle pans out! (Yes, I'm shamelessly trying to rile the pan vs. zoom crowd). 

A scene from O. Henry's "Seats of the Haughty":

"At six o'clock me and Solly sat down to dinner. Spread! There's nothing been seen like it since the Cambon snack. It was all served at once. The chef called it dinnay √† la poker. It's a famous thing among the gourmands of the West. The dinner comes in threes of a kind. There was guinea-fowls, guinea-pigs, and Guinness's stout; roast veal, mock turtle soup, and chicken p√¢t√©; shad-roe, caviar, and tapioca; canvas-back duck, canvas-back ham, and cotton-tail rabbit; Philadelphia capon, fried snails, and sloe-gin‚Äîand so on, in threes. The idea was that you eat nearly all you can of them, and then the waiter takes away the discard and gives you pears to fill on."

Tuesday puzzles have been great, lately. 

Much prefer a Tuesday that‚Äôs closer to a Wednesday than a Monday.

This one was still simple enough but still checked the ego in just the right way when I first got started and expected to breeze through.

Done but one (at least I hope there's only one) typo, which I cannot find.  I can recite the whole puzzle now, having been through it about a dozen times, and it's solid as a rock, this construction, which may account for my difficulty in crushing it.

I love these clues (Green day was perfect) but do I really need to know all the fills so intimately?  

Sigh, back to work.
Coincidentally, I tried the word HIED in the Monday Spelling Bee. It was not accepted, but it was totally on my mind when I read the clue for 29 across.
Woohoo!  Hit my 1000 streak today!
That was fun!  Congratulations on your debut, Gene.  Looking forward to the next one.
Actual words are much more fun to solve than idiomatic slang phrases and proper names of the obscure - I blame the apps crossword makers use for throwing up too much dross filler.

At one point, I stopped solving to check the day of the week. What a crunchy Tuesday! (But not, erm, painfully so.) I wondered about Sting, the self -described "KING of Pain," and what exclamations he might have used. Probably not publishable, lest The Police of emus be awakened from their slumber. https://youtu.be/SZlRX03BzeA?si=CiZJj1Cv0rbdXH3J Congratulations on and thank you for a delightful debut, Gene! It's been a very real pleasure to solve your puzzle.
It‚Äôs rare I learn a new word while solving a Tuesday puzzle but HIED was new to me.

Ms Sam asks about "shoot" as an exclamation of pain. I can't give you the etymology but I immediately thought of the version that means new growth of plants. I'd say that "shoot" is a perfect solve for a puzzle about growing pains.

Congratulations on a nice debut, Mr. de Vera! I had the pleasure of writing it up for Diary of a Crossword Fiend. https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/04/28/tuesday-april-29-2025/#ny I hope we'll see you back here soon!
Dang it -- I got caught by Jed Clampett and a Spanish bear.

Despite the theme, this puzzle was pretty painless for me. 

Favorite clue: Blues group for DNC, which is apt in more than one way these days. üò¢
Did not enjoy seeing HOTORNOT. We were absolutely horrible to young women in the public eye in the 2000s.
That is not what a tangent line is

Nice debut, Gene. Had me going for a while, but I managed to get this squared away without too much trouble.

Had to dig HIED out of the memory banks, but it's certainly not a new word for me. Was not familiar with HOT OR NOT, as I don't ever recall seeing anything about it, let alone visiting it.

you know - for 8D a double decker checker is KING in a checkers game. two stacked checker pieces signify a king. but only when it reaches the end of the opposite side of the board. 

quite a clever clue.
I think HBO (now MAX) might take exception to being clued by their ‚Äúold‚Äù name!
Today 29A or went in haste solves to a word that today's Spelling Bee rejects. And it's not a proper noun either.
Can we dispense with the words "chewy" and "crunchy" to describe puzzles? I think their time has come and gone.

Double decker checker is not the King in chess, it is when a checker is moved all the way to the opponents first row whereupon you put another checker on top of it making it "double decker". It can then move in both directions.

Two comments:
1) it really seems like a slap in the face to the crossword gods to have ‚Äúsmoked‚Äù and ‚Äúcaviar‚Äù right next to each other and not take the opportunity to clue them together. Even on a Tuesday‚Äîjust clue the downs more gently if needed.
2) maybe this is a nit‚Äîand I‚Äôm happy to retract it if I‚Äôm wrong‚Äîbut I don‚Äôt think you can ‚Äústarve for attention‚Äù. You may be ‚Äústarved for attention‚Äù (ie very hungry) or ‚Äústarving for attention‚Äù which means the same thing, but that‚Äôs still a prepositional adjective and not a verb form. ‚ÄúStarve for attention‚Äù sounds like you are physically not eating to get attention, which I suppose you can do, but that‚Äôs not the normal usage.
Hamlet tells Ophelia, "Hie thee to a nunnery!" Remembering the Old Bard comes in handy.

I got stuck for longer than I would have liked with O?O crossing [Buddy] EB?EN and RO? [Asquith] crossing ?TPATS. For the first one, I had ‚Äòr‚Äô which seemed like as good a guess as any (thought OrO might be related to ursus). It was one of those cases where you take a guess and forget about it and it becomes an unknown unknown. For the second one, I just couldn‚Äôt see any letter that would make them both make sense, and tried every letter without luck (due to the other error). Should have just taken a break and come back fresh tomorrow.

I'm surprised there isn't more beefing about STARVE. In my head, it doesn't fit. To starve someone of attention means to deny attention. To be starved for attention means to long for attention. I can't create a sentence with "starve for" that makes sense. I don't think "they starve for attention" works. Am I missing it? Unless as SP mentioned, we're talking about a hunger strike.
GOOD QUIZ TODAY LADS I REALLY LIKED IT TWO BIG THUMS UP FROM ME

A steady Tuesday. A little crunchy but quite doable (sorry @BJ, but that is the word that works for me. Perhaps skip over my comments if it‚Äôs too cringey for youü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è).
Happy to see I‚Äôm not the only one caught in the EB?N/O?O trap. A Spanish word crossing an unknown actor in an unknown programme will get me every time. The joys of international crossword solving.

Glad to see the lights come back on in Spain and Portugal. That must have been scary.
Another quick day two to give me that extra kick for the week, which seems like a more natural clue than extra punch?

Fast puzzle.
It took me an embarasingly long to figure out "green day"
Spanish Bear no problem, but Game
 of Thrones actor was a long shot guess.

OOPS--double-decker checker is a KING as in what happens when you reach the opposite end of the board and you say: "King me."

Some clean expressions of pains could be: moan, groan, argh, bleh, yeek. When I broke my ankle in three places the first thing I said was: "I broke both of my feet." LOL.
Congratulations on your debut , Gene.  I‚Äôm looking forward to more.

Nice puzzle.  The one thing I did not love was the ROS/STPATS clue.  Does anyone call it Saint Pats?  Any variation on Saint Paddy's or Patty's seems fine, but St. Pats (especially sneaking in the abbreviation)--maybe not so much.  I did not love that, especially because ROS Asquith seems relatively obscure to me.

Nice Tuesday workout. A bit on the slow side for me, and must admit I didn't really catch on to the trick until I was almost done. No big deal - just made for a nice 'aha' moment. One clue history search today was for TANGENT. Just wondered if it had ever been clued as a two word phrase. Yep - but mostly only in variety puzzles. And early in my life when I was doing outdoor labor, that definitely would have applied to me. But that did lead me to one of the more remarkable puzzles I've ever seen - a Sunday from February 12, 2017 by Lynn Lempel with the title "Do the splits." In that one the clue/answer was: "Berate some guy for getting too much sun?" GOOFFONATANGENT And... some other theme answers, which I've divided as implied by the clues: POE TRY READING LAB OR PARTY JUST ICE FOR ALL FAT AL ATTRACTION FUMANCHU MUST ACHE And there were more. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/12/2017&g=23&d=A I'll put some other puzzle finds in replies. ....

flED before HIED, sicEM before GET EM, that *never* happens on a Tuesday.  I liked it!  I'm very much looking forward to Gene's upcoming themeless.

As for the column photo, I think the "GENT" will regret his decision when his friend takes her next step.  

Talk about OUCH........
a double decker checker isn't a chess piece it's a checker piece. when you reach the other end of the board you say KING ME and get another piece on top of the piece or checker you already have.

Thoughts:
‚Ä¢	Quality debut, with hardly a whiff of junk and a pitch-perfect Tuesday theme.
‚Ä¢	That theme is original, BTW, never done before in the major crossword outlets.
‚Ä¢	Sweet that the pain answers not only grow in size, but also grow from down to up.
‚Ä¢	If your solving time was a little longer than usual, could be because the grid has an extra column.
‚Ä¢	Beauty in answer: SCEPTER, ON A WHIM, OOMPH.
‚Ä¢	Touch of irony in that the answer NO CLUE has one.
‚Ä¢	Very nice that both chess and checkers are represented.
‚Ä¢	Serendipities: The lovely abutting PuzzPair¬© of SMOKED/CAVIAR, rare-in-crosswords five-letter semordnilap (ELIOT), and ooh ‚Äì five double O‚Äôs!

Much promise here, and I eagerly await your coming themeless, Gene.  Thank you for a splendid outing!

I certainly agree that a photo shoot is a huge pain, especially at a large family gathering. Like herding cats.

Anyone else find themselves correcting their posture with 32D? 
I liked today's puzzle a lot--I love when early week puzzles have a theme/trick, I remember when I was a new crossword solver and Monday/Tuesday were the only puzzles I could routinely solve without help or checking the answers, and it was always nice to get to figure out a theme!
Good job Gene Louise -- looking forward to next month!

Perfectly decent Tuesday puzzle.  I found it a bit on the easy side, but YMMV.

I loved the clue "Double decker checker".  I assume I wasn't the only one who was thinking that there must be a name for the official who checks for tickets on the top of a double decker bus.  (A bit shocking, however, that Sam thought that this was a chess reference, when "checker" is in the clue!)

Took me almost 14 minutes, and felt like a Wednesday puzzle to me. Especially the central and southern zones.

The 16 x 15 grid with left-right symmetry was unusual, as was the theme itself. Liked "Double-decker checker" for KING, which I only understood upon review of the completed puzzle. (Double-decker had me thinking of buses or burgers, and checker was a person who checked on things.)

Not sure GROWINGPAINS quite works for me, but we do have  a sequence of interjections of increasing length. Don't think I've ever exclaimed SHOOT upon stubbing a toe, but have probably uttered the other three (along with quite a few others that would never be countenanced by the emus).

Congrats on the debut!

Was so super excited to see TANGENT LINES! 

Esoteric finance stuff ahead: 

I teach a class in Fixed Income and one of the concepts is estimating how much a bond's price changes for a given change in interest rates. The actual relation is non-linear (convex) and so we approximate the change with a tangent line. 

The slope of the TANGENT LINE is called duration, and it's a super important concept for bond investors because it gives them a very intuitive sense of price volatility of their bond for a 1 percent (100 basis point) change in yields. Longer term bonds generally have higher duration (in case you're wondering) and this is why investors prefer short term bonds in times of financial uncertainty (like I don't know, right now.)

I'm always jumping up and down and drawing pictures on the board when I teach this. 

Can't wait to show this puzzle to my Fall students. 

If both TANGENT LINES and DURATION showed up in the same puzzle, my life would be complete ü§£ü§£.

Very nice Tuesday puzzle. It took some time, but was entertaining instead of frustrating (always a good thing).
Unlike some commenters, I found 44A and 35D right in my wheelhouse.  But "Green day" was brilliant misdirection (could it be the band, but not capitalized? Or maybe Earth Day?). 

The theme was entertaining, and didn't add any extra difficulty. (No pain.)

Looking forward to Gene's next puzzle!
Very nice debut with a toothsome, dare I say chewy, finish towards the bottom but the S of STPATS was the last to fill.  Many thanks.
I saw the bars and got the revealer off the bat then solved from the bottom to see what the "pains" would be.
Tough on for me. Very little was clicking. Still, a good puzzle. Thanks!

So, TIL that "inspiriting" is a word. I've managed to get quite old without consciously registering it. No doubt it'll crop up twice in the next week.
I've also managed to get quite old without ever watching a game show in my adult life. What's inspiriting about DING? It was the sound that brought up the next word in "Call My Bluff" when I was a kid, but that generally elicited despairing groans.

GROWING PAINS got me through this one---just enough traction from the theme to get me past a bunch of unknowns. 
(My grandmother was convinced that it hurt when your bones grew, and wasn't going to let anyone with something so trivial as a medical degree convince her otherwise.)
I thought TANGENT crossing with GENT was a little lazy and uninspired

Cartilaginous for a Tuesday, but without any negative connotation.

I've never had any cleaning brands say anything to me.


Lies, all lies!
(Lysol lies)

The theme seems a bit clunky to me, since what is "growing" in the puzzle is the length of the interjections brought about by events that cause pain.

If it's the pains that are actually growing (reading 21A literally), then the largest pain should illicit the loudest and most colorful expletive.  And in that case, SHOOT just doesn't cut it.

Very nice today. Not too many film stars.

I call checkers 'draughts' but don't know where that comes from. When a piece gets to the end of the board it's 'crowned' and is called a 'crowner.'
I enjoyed this one overall except for the middle, which was horrible imperceptible due to vague clues and HIED (not a thing) at the top. Otherwise, I look forward to more from this constructor!

Some of the complaints about idioms and abbreviations "these days" (supposedly due to crossword-construction apps) made me wonder if we haven't always had these in crosswords, so I took a look at Tuesday, November 23, 1993 (the oldest Tuesday in the archive) to see whether the puzzles were any better back then. Obviously a somewhat random sample, but we have:

RST (Alphabetic run)
OHS (Words of wonderment)
OOH (Cry of delight [in the same puzzle as OHS, for shame!])
OSE (Sugary suffix)
ABELL (Sound as _____)
GOTTA (Must, slangily)
PPPS (Third addendum to a letter)

Even EBSEN made an appearance, just as it did today. The more things change, the more they stay the same!

OW, OOF, OUCH....those are familiar sounds around here.  (Why are kitchen cabinets installed at a height that means the door opens just above eye-level, where one can walk right into it and THWACK?  A cruel reminder to close the cabinet Every Time.)

But SHOOT?  Not EEYOW?  Not DAMN?  
My dear Gene, how very inadequate to the occasion of incurring maximum pain.  
Well, maybe you were thinking, "SHOOT me now!"  Which I have been known to say, but not usually relating to physical PAINS....

Oh well.  Main slow-downs here were choosing between SNARL and SCOWL and then STRIVE and STARVE.  On with my day!
SHOOT as the ultimate expression of pain is remarkably mild, a sly little wink-wink joke.

Re: 29A. There was an old computer game called Colossal Cave and it involved navigating a maze of twisty passages, all alike; or a twisty maze of passages, all different. It was entirely text based and had rudimentary language understanding. This was 1978, remember. 

To achieve the high score of 350, one had to encounter the pirate, who would steal whatever treasure you were carrying and HIE off with it. I rarely see that word any more, and it was a delightful to have it appear this morning.
SHOOT! My first thought on solving 21A was that the shaded boxes would be "pa, pai, pain, pains". That was ERRANT, but it would have been fun. I haven't played checkers in years. KING me!
Theme was clever but to me, pretty sloppy puzzle for a Tuesday. Too many archaic words, slang (when not notated), along with obscure people or myths: HIED? ROS (Aaquith)? GETEM.
I'm quite impressed with the crossword set by the two kids. Very well done!

shouldn‚Äôt ‚Äúdouble decker checker‚Äù refer to, not chess, but checkers? In checkers, when a piece is ‚Äúkinged‚Äù, an additional piece of the same color is placed on top of the first piece. 
I don‚Äôt play chess but I don‚Äôt see how a king could get doubled that way in chess.
Well, that certainly got my brain to stop slouching this morning. Thanks for the wake up call, Gene!

How the heck does ONYX derive from "claw?"

"Hey, look at this cool rock I found! What should I call it?"
"Hmm, it's really black, reminds me of a claw."
"Seriously? Well, I guess so, ONYX it is."

I think the Greeks smoked a lot of dope.

this was pretty hard for me. After 20 min I gave up and needed 17 revealed squares. I dont always finish Tuesday but usually if I fail i will only need 1-5 reveals. The theme is not even worthy of a groan. Seems like an afterthought.
For some reason ‚Äúoof‚Äù makes me smile every time I see it.

I see one of the earliest comments was about the origin of photo heading the Wordplay column, but no mention of exactly why Sam chose this particular photo.

Oh, sorry, I forgot, to drive us crazy. I guess I'll just reflect on it like a Zen koan, although if anyone can enlighten me, feel free.
I liked the puzzle because it had really fresh fill within a Tuesday level of difficulty. Made me smile.

I think this is a fun, well done, and appropriate Tuesday.  
There were 3 totally unknowns for me, but easily filled from crosses. And I started it too late in the evening and was tired so got stuck on some wordplay. 
After a good nights sleep, a fun puppy romp, crossing off ‚Äúeradicate fire ants‚Äù from my to do list (hopefully for a few months at least), I was able to finish the crossword before breakfast. A satisfying morning. 

Honestly, I don‚Äôt know how anyone wouldn‚Äôt smile at OOF. 

Thanks Gene Louise de Vera, and congrats on your NYT debut!

I didn‚Äôt know what 10 down was, so I had to get 25 across correct. And the only thing I could think of for blues group was university of North Carolina that were blue so I used UNC instead of DNC.üò±

Apologies if this has been posted already, but some might be interested to know that (improbably enough) the fella with the woman running across his chest, pictured at the head of the Wordplay column, is none other than British national treasure, the satirist Peter Cook.
The scene was filmed for a very short-lived chat show, hosted by Cook, entitled "Where Do I Sit?"

I think your interpretation for the answer for 8D may be a bit off course. I don't play chess but in the game of checkers, when your piece reaches the back of the opposing side a second checker is put on top of it and it becomes a king, able to roam the board at will. That's how I interpreted that clue.
Hied, as in 'hie thee hence?"

Of course, most racehorses' feet are SHOD--but then, so are the feet of many other horses (not to mention their riders/drovers). Wanna know what racehorse feet have that most other horses' don't? The have a moment when not one of the four are touching the earth: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UHzcNlVwP3E (never seen, never seen that picture before . . .)

to quote Sir Percy: Sink me!

Nice one Gene.

One could look at a salmon on a plate and reference it as "smoked" as in offed, kilt, etc.

As an Irish person, St Pats is very very VERY wrong. Nobody refers to our patron saint as Pat. Its St Patricks Day, or familiarly, it's Paddy's Day.
I wont even start on Patty's Day....
hied is a crazy word to keep in a puzzle lol
Worst puzzle ever. "hit the roof"? "hot or not"? That whole middle section, blech. Luckily, the answers hit the bottom w/ "murse" not too long ago. Happy spring, all.

I really am a latecomer to O. Henry, but he's not just a one trick pony. And some of his stories have exquisite prose. Here's a single paragraph from "Hearts and Roses."

At Dry Lake, where their routes diverged, they reined up for a parting cigarette. For miles they had ridden in silence save for the soft drum of the ponies' hoofs on the matted mesquite grass, and the rattle of the chaparral against their wooden stirrups. But in Texas discourse is seldom continuous. You may fill in a mile, a meal, and a murder between your paragraphs without detriment to your thesis. So, without apology, Webb offered an addendum to the conversation that had begun ten miles away.

@john ezra

Plus, I really like his candy bar.

@Jack Sullivan

I look for a pangram as soon as I open the puzzle because my brain hasn't carved out any paths yet and I'm almost always able to see it. I can't remember ever making Queen Bee, but I never stop until I hit Genius. So far:

640 Puzzles
20,551 Words
785 Pangrams
637 Geniuses

I suspect that this isn't much different from most people's scores, but it's good enough for me.

@Patrick

I think it is.

My understanding is that for a smoothly changing function, the best approximation of that curve at some point is the tangent line of the curve at that point.  

It will fit the actual point perfectly, and will minimize the discrepancy in the neighborhood of that point.
@Patrick really? Can you cite any sources?

@Patrick @Francis @Ben

The slope of the curve is defined to be the slope of the tangent line at that point. A small segment of the tangent line through the point approximates the curve in the sense that as the length of the segment shrinks the segment itself gets closer to the curve at that point. So, technically, it's the small pieces of the line that approximate the curve. This is actually analytic geometry which is commonly taught with calculus. So, any technical calculus book (one used for teaching math, science, engineering students) would be a good reference. Sorry, any specific book I can name is likely to be out of date.
@Mollie Black is a trend line different and a better match to the clue?
@Patrick I wonder if "secant line" might be what the clue more closely describes.
@Patrick Close enough for this professional mathematician. Though "Figures that are local approximations of curves, in calculus" seems better.
@Patrick see my other post, in bond pricing we call it a tangent line.

@Paul 
I don't think of a trend line as being defined as strictly as a tangent line. It probably depends on what area of study the people using the term are in. I think the term is commonly used in finance but I think there the definition is not strict. In this case, 2 people could have slightly different trend lines. I have also seen the term used for what I would call a regression line. In both cases, I don't think people are starting with a curve and trying to approximate it. I think they start with a bunch of separate points and are try trying to approximate them.

It probably helps to be an American of a certain age to have Buddy Ebsen as a gimme answer. The Beverly Hillbillies was a number one TV program in the sixties, and also spawned a spin-off, Petticoat Junction. Ebsen started out as a dancer in the twenties and transitioned to a popular TV star at the end of his long career, with roles as varied as a private eye and Davy Crockett‚Äôs sidekick, in addition to the Arkansas hayseed who found oil on his property.

@Vislander

Some of us spent *far* too much time back then watching the above-mentioned TV programs. Trivia: Buddy Ebsen was originally cast as the Scarecrow in "The Wizard of Oz", then his role was changed to the Tin Man. He was allergic to the (poisonous) silver makeup and had to drop out of the movie.

@Mean Old Lady

Some kids get benign leg pain, sometimes. But it's not caused by "growing bones". It's a mixture of lots of exercise and immature collagen in connective tissue, probably.
A paediatric rhematologist of my acquaintance was making it his life's work to stamp out the phrase "growing pains". 

(Well, he did other things, too.)

Another corker of folk wisdom from my grandmother, accepted uncritically by my parents, was that teenagers can "outgrow their strength". That one caused me a lot of pointless misery.

(On the up side, she did smuggle me pickled onions  under the table whenever we visited.)

@Oikofuge There is a fair amount of medical literature out there regarding GROWINGPAINS. As you indicate, the very common belief held by your grandmother that these are due to rapid bone growth has never been substantiated. There was an editorial in the British Medical Journal some years ago which did a pretty good job of summarizing the issues involved. As always, thanks for your great comments! See: https://tinyurl.com/39zbuveh
@Mean Old Lady   Growing pains in the chest at age 12. I had them.  I recall also that it was decided they were real.   Something about the rapidity of the growth, I'm sure.

@Hardroch

Thanks for that. The problem with "Recurrent Limb Pain in Childhood" is, of course, that parents find it an unsatisfactory label, because it just repeats back to them what they already know. Whereas "growing pains" sounds like a *diagnosis*.

My colleague wanted something like "Pain of the Maturing Musculoskeletal System", which has a reassuring ring to it, and gets away from the spurious connection to "growing".

But his main concern was that some parents were dismissing significant bone and joint pain because they had this idea that significant bone pain is a normal part of growing.

Grant, I didn't know either, so I looked it up. "So called because the mineral's color sometimes resembles that of a human fingernail, pink with white streaks." https://www.etymonline.com/word/onyx

@Grant

Yeah, I thought the clue was a bit of a stretch / misdirection. The name derives from the Greek for "fingernail", which happens to be their word for "claw", too. 

Dinosaurs with names ending in "-onyx" (like Baryonyx) have names that *really* derive from the Greek word for "claw".

You may (or may not) be interested to know that a person who bites their fingernails is an "onychophagist"---a "nail eater", not a "claw eater".

@Barry Ancona
I looked it up too, but I didn't quite get the "fingernail" reference to mean a variety of the stone that wasn't black. I'm curious as to how the constructor got there.

@Grant
To add to what our Scottish anaesthetist has already pointed out, we also have medical-speak onychomycosis (nail fungus), onychoschizia (split nails), and onychogryphosis (thick/curled nails). The term ‚Äúungula‚Äù has also been used, as in subungual hematoma, or a bruise under a nail. Of the 148 times ONYX has been clued, this was a first. Nice job!

@Hardroch

And paronychia ("beside the nail"), for an infection around the nail edges---commonly called a whitlow in my part of the world, but I'm not sure how well that will cross the Atlantic.

@Hardroch
Thanks, now I know what to call it when I whack my thumb with a hammer. (I don't say SHOOT when that happens.)

@NYC Traveler

As some will know, subungual haematomata (for that is the plural), are exquisitely painful, because of the pressure build-up under the nail. Release the pressure---pain goes away.
So releasing that pressure in the ER ("Casualty", as it used to be known in the UK) was immensely satisfying. 
Back in the day, we used a paperclip and a cigarette lighter. I'm sure there's some very expensive gizmo that does the same thing, these days.
You partially straighten the paper clip, so that you have the sort of "tool" that you can improvise to push the recessed reset button on some electronic devices. Then you heat the end to red heat with the cigarette lighter. Then you *lightly* rest the hot end on the patient's nail, over the haematoma. Smoke rises as the hot end burns through the nail ...

Suspense mounts ...

And as soon as the clip burns through the nail, it's flipped upwards by the pressure of the confined blood, which squirts dramatically into the air.

Patient heaves a sigh of relief, shakes hands with doctor, and goes home with a tale to tell that no-one will believe.

@Ciar√°n

In a different thread, I noted how Americans and Brits say many things differently. The same is true about Americans and Irish. Whereas ST PATS seems very wrong to you, it‚Äôs fairly common and normal here. 

Irish immigrants brought their culture to the US, but things diverged somewhat. For example, here, a typical ‚ÄúIrish‚Äù meal for March 17, whatever you call the day, is corned beef and cabbage, which is not typical in Ireland. 

In a similar vein, Cinco de Mayo is the ‚Äúbig Mexican holiday‚Äù in the US, whereas it‚Äôs not a major holiday in most of Mexico. And we consider hard-shelled tacos to be the quintessential Mexican dish, but they‚Äôre virtually unknown south of the border. 

Similarly, spaghetti and meatballs, our idea of a typical Italian meal, is barely found in Italy.  Most supposedly Chinese dishes were invented in the US and are unknown in China. 

Cultures come to the US and do their own thing. So if you visit us in March, be prepared to have corned beef and cabbage on ST. PAT‚ÄôS day. At least the shamrock is still the same.
